awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual merit.  The research is directed at determining the role of chemical communication among bacteria in biofilm formation. A small molecule known as autoinducer 2 (AI-2) is produced and secreted by diverse species of bacteria. High levels of AI-2 accumulate when cells exist at high density, as they do in the mixed-species aggregates known as biofilms. Biofilms frequently coat the surfaces of both natural and man-made surfaces, and cells living within them are protected from many chemical, physical, and biological agents that threaten free-living bacteria. We find that AI-2 is a potent chemoattractant for E. coli and have identified two proteins that serve as the receptor for AI-2. The project has two aims. (1) To determine the mechanism by which the AI-2 binding protein LsrB interacts with the transmembrane signal-transducer protein Tsr to initiate a chemotaxis response. (2) To determine whether AI-2 attracts free-swimming E. coli cells to biofilms and helps them to adapt themselves metabolically to biofilm life.

Broader impacts.  The research will be pursued in part by undergraduate and graduate students, who will receive training in molecular biology, bacterial physiology, and microfluidic nanotechnology. The research will be closely integrated with course work. The research is highly interdisciplinary. The investigators include a molecular microbiologist, a chemical engineer, a physical biochemist, and a synthetic organic chemist. This provides an excellent opportunity for training students. In addition, the research addresses an important environmental problem. Biofilms foul surfaces and serve as reservoirs for harmful bacteria in a variety of habitats. Knowledge about the chemical signals bacteria use to coordinate their activities to form and maintain unwanted biofilms can be applied to combat them.

por.por_cntn:
Bacteria are single-celled organisms. However, they do not always live solitary lives. They gather in highly cooperative groups called biofilms. Biofilms typically form on surfaces, and they are everywhere: in pipes, on rocks, in toilets, and on any other surfaces that are wet. They also form on plants and inside of animals, including us.

Biofilms provide many advantages to their inhabitants. They offer protection against predators, antibiotics, detergents and other harmful chemical agents. They allow for efficient processing of nutrients that can only be broken down by collections of bacteria. They also enable behaviors that are only meaningful for collectives of bacteria, like the production of toxins or bioluminescence.

To form biofilms, bacteria must communicate their population density. They do this chemically, in a process called quorum sensing. Cells synthesize and secrete small molecules called autoinducers, which they can also detect. When the local accumulation of the autoinducer reaches a certain critical concentration, it initiates intracellular signals that turn on expression of genes whose products are needed for collective behavior. Some autoinducers, called AI-1, are highly specific and only allow for information to be shared within very closely related species. Other autoinducers can be produced and sensed by a very wide diversity of bacteria. AI-2 is an autoinducer of the latter type, being generated and sensed by many species of Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria.

We discovered some years ago that AI-2 (R-tetrahydroxy-methyl-furan) is a potent chemoattractant for the common gut bacterium Escherichia coli. This discovery naturally raised the question of whether AI-2 produced by E. coli promotes the aggregation of cells that is the first step in biofilm formation.

The work funded by this grant answered that question in the affirmative. Using cells that express the green fluorescent protein (GFP), which allows individuals bacteria to be visualized by fluorescence microscopy, we found that cells unable to produce AI-2, cells unable to perform chemotaxis to AI-2, and cells unable to take up AI-2 from the environment were all delayed in aggregation into cell clusters and were also defective in biofilm formation. Although we only studied E. coli, it is reasonable to think that bacteria unable to respond to AI-2 would be impaired in their ability to join multi-species biofilms, which should be potent sources of AI-2.

Cells are most responsive to AI-2 as an attractant before they start producing significant amounts of AI-2 themselves. This makes sense, as self-produced AI-2 should saturate the AI-2 receptors of the cells producing it and make it impossible for them to respond well to external gradients of AI-2. A model is suggested in which planktonic, free-swimming bacteria at low density sense concentration gradients of AI-2 and swim toward the source. Thus, AI-2 gradients could serve as a chemical beacon that would draw planktonic cells to incipient biofilms in the early stages of development. This behavior could be advantageous to both free-living bacteria and to bacteria inside the host, as biofilms can form on the intestinal epithelium. As pathogenic E. coli stains also respond to AI-2 as a chemoattractant, AI-2 chemotaxis could be an important virulence factor, and thus disruption of AI-2 chemotaxis has promise as a therapeutic measure.

We also characterized the molecular mechanism of AI-2 sensing. AI-2 first binds to a soluble protein, LsrB, that is present in the periplasmic space between the inner and outer membranes of Gram-negative E. coli. After undergoing a conformational change upon binding AI-2, LsrB interacts with the transmembrane chemoreceptor Tsr, already well-characterized as the receptor for the chemoattractant serine. A thorough mutational analysis allowed us to predict how LsrB and Tsr interact and to develop a molecular-docking model for the LsrB/Tsr complex.

We thus were able to complete both of our objectives: to determine the molecular mechanism of AI-2 sensing that leads to chemoattraction to sources of AI-2 and to demonstrate that our hypothesis that AI-2 chemotaxis is important for biofilm formation is true. Several peer-reviewed papers and book chapters describing this work have already been published, another paper is nearing completion, and work on the biochemical details of the interactions of AI-2 with LsrB and of LsrB with Tsr are in progress.

In addition to the peer-reviewed publications, this work has led to PhD dissertations for two students in the Manson lab, Sneha Jani and Andrew Seely. Dr. Jani is currently a postdoctoral fellow at the Lawrence/Berkeley labs, and Dr. Seely has a faculty position at the University of Arkansas Community College Batesville. Numerous undergraduates participated in the research, and several of them will be authors on the paper that is currently in preparation. One MS student and a number of undergraduates are also carrying on some of the ongoing work. We therefore think that the project has been successful both in its intellectual contribution and for its broader educational significance.
